Graphical abstract Active site occlusion by carbon species, often referred to as coke, is a common deactivation mechanism for heterogeneous catalysts. While it is known that transition metals can lower the temperature required for oxidative coke removal, the roles of ionic species and metal nanoparticles in coke removal are not well understood. This work aims to differentiate how ionic and nanoparticle Cu sites catalyze oxidative regeneration of a coked beta (BEA) zeolite catalyst. This was accomplished by synthesizing catalysts containing exclusively CuOx nanoparticles (NPs) or Cu2+ ions supported on BEA, physically mixing Cu/BEA with a coked BEA catalyst, and monitoring coke removal using in situ spectroscopy. Our results point to an improved combustion activity for CuOx NPs relative to Cu2+ ions, especially in the combustion of graphitic-type coke species. This improved understanding of coke combustion in transition metal containing catalysts informs strategies to improve catalyst regeneration, thereby increasing operational lifetimes. Keywords Cu/BEA Renewable fuels Catalyst regeneration Multi-functional catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The deposition of carbonaceous species onto catalyst surfaces is a necessary side reaction of hydrocarbon chemistry under most conditions.[1] Often referred to under the umbrella term, “coke”, the deposited carbon can take a variety of forms including amorphous carbon, polycyclic molecules, alkyl benzenes, and branched aliphatic molecules.[1] Although these species often serve as important intermediates or co-catalysts for hydrocarbon production chemistries,[2] they can also lead to catalyst deactivation by occluding active sites either through surface coverage or pore blockage.[3]. Numerous strategies have been devised to extend the lifetimes of catalysts by removing accumulated coke species including treatment of the catalyst with high temperature oxygen, steam, and other oxidants.[4] When catalysts are regenerated using oxygen, coke species are removed as carbon dioxide through combustion reactions. This process can occur either non-catalytically at the surface of the coke when oxygen reacts directly with the coke surface,[5] or with the assistance of catalytic surface sites which may participate in the coke oxidation mechanism by activating gas-phase oxygen.[6,7] In many cases, the removal of coke at temperatures below 500 °C is attractive to avoid catalyst damage via sintering, or in the case of zeolite catalysts, dealumination at high temperatures (e.g., >700 °C).[8] Previous reports have demonstrated that the addition of metals,[9,10] acid sites,[11–13] and other surface additives enable coke combustion at temperatures up to 200 °C below those of the unmodified catalyst.[13]. Understanding coke combustion over catalysts containing multiple active site types, including BrØnsted acid sites, metallic sites, and ionic metal sites is further complicated by the unique catalytic activity of each site type for coke combustion. For instance, numerous reports have shown differences in catalytic activity for metal species ranging from single atoms to clusters to nanoparticles (NPs).[14–16] In some cases, synergy has even been demonstrated between single metal atom sites and metal NPs.[17,18] With these findings in mind, it is of interest to understand how the speciation of a supported metal affects coke removal. In this report, we focus on supported Cu, a metal that exhibits activity with zeolites for a variety of complete combustion,[19–21] selective oxidation,[22,23] and carbon–carbon coupling reactions.[17,24–26] Specifically, this work focuses on a Cu-modified beta (BEA) zeolite, which our group has studied for dimethyl ether (DME) homologation to transportation fuels.[17,25–29] Our previous results have shown that Cu/BEA catalysts are much more active for fuel production than BEA alone.[25] We have also proposed that catalysts synthesized via incipient wetness impregnation contain populations of Cu nanoparticles, which hydrogenate olefins that could oligomerize into aromatic molecules or coke, and ionic Cu sites that facilitate hydrogen transfer reactions to enhance olefin oligomerization to longer chain products, with both Cu functionalities working in tandem to increase the productivity of aliphatic molecules with four to seven carbons.[17] This homologation to branched hydrocarbons is known to generate both molecular aromatic coke species as well as graphitic coke.[10] While we have previously demonstrated that the presence of Cu on BEA decreases the onset temperature of coke combustion by over 100 °C, it is unclear if CuOx NPs or ionic Cu2+ sites are responsible for the improved low temperature coke removal.[10] Understanding the role of individual transition metal sites in the coke removal mechanism will help design future catalysts for milder regeneration cycles. This is particularly important for catalysts used in processes that utilize renewable feedstocks, which present increased deactivation concerns relative to traditional petroleum feedstocks due to their increased complexity.[30]. To investigate the role of CuOx NPs and Cu2+ ions on coke removal individually, we here report the combustion of coke from a single deactivated H-BEA zeolite catalyst physically mixed with BEA materials containing a single Cu site type. The use of a single deactivated catalyst ensures that an identical coke composition is combusted using each Cu-containing material. We emphasize that a constant coke composition is important because previous reports have demonstrated that different catalysts create unique coke species, which may undergo combustion at different temperatures under identical reaction atmospheres.[10,19,29] The combustion of coke from the physical mixtures was monitored in situ using a variety of techniques including thermogravimetric analysis, diffuse reflectance UV–Vis spectroscopy, and Raman spectroscopy. Through this approach, we identified that ionic Cu2+ species performed similarly to CuOx NPs for the combustion of hydrocarbon coke molecules, but CuOx NPs exhibited improved performance for the combustion of graphitic-type coke compounds. These findings clarify the relative performance of ionic metal sites and NPs in coke combustion, which can be used to design effective catalyst regeneration protocols that remove catalyst coke while avoiding severe conditions that may degrade catalyst performance. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Catalyst synthesis 2.1.1 Beta zeolite catalyst Beta zeolite (BEA) having a SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 27 (Si/Al = 13.5) was obtained in ammonium form from Tosoh and had an agglomerate size range of 45–125 μm. The BEA zeolite was calcined under flowing air at 550 °C to give the proton-form. 2.1.2 Post-reaction BEA catalyst The post-reaction BEA catalyst was generated following a protocol from our recent report.[10] BEA powders were pressed, crushed in a porcelain mortar and pestle, and sieved to a particle size of 212–300 μm (50–70 mesh) for catalytic evaluation. The catalyst (0.6 g) was diluted with 3.6 g of low surface-area, inert silicon carbide (60–70 mesh) to achieve a constant catalyst bed volume and to minimize channeling, axial dispersion, and temperature gradients in the bed. Catalysts were loaded into a 7.9 mm ID stainless-steel tubular reactor and positioned within the isothermal zone using quartz chips and quartz wool. A four-point thermocouple positioned within the catalyst bed was used to monitor and control reaction temperature. The reaction temperature was maintained within ± 0.5 °C of the set point by a 3-zone furnace. The catalyst was reduced in flowing H2 (25 sccm, UHP, Matheson) by heating at 5 °C/min to 300 °C and holding at this temperature for 3 h before cooling to the reaction temperature of 200 °C. When the temperature was stabilized at 200 °C, the reactant mixture consisting of 6.1 sccm DME (Matheson), 6.1 sccm H2, and 1.0 sccm Ar (UHP, Matheson) was passed over the catalyst to achieve a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 1.2 gDME/gcat/h, and a H2 to DME molar ratio of 1:1. Ar was used as an internal standard. The catalyst was collected from the reactor after 24 h on stream. The post-reaction catalyst is denoted PR-BEA. 2.1.3 Colloidal CuOx nanoparticles synthesis Colloidal CuOx nanoparticles (NPs) were prepared via a solution synthesis route adapted from Yin, et al.[31] A mixture of anhydrous copper(I) acetate (490 mg, 99 %, Strem), oleic acid (4 mL, 90 %, Sigma Aldrich), and trioctylamine (15 mL, 98 %, Sigma Aldrich) was heated to 100 °C at 10 °C/min in a round-bottom 3-neck flask under vacuum and held for 1 h with vigorous stirring. The flask was then backfilled with N2 and heated to 180 °C at 10 °C/min and maintained at this temperature for 1 h, before heating to 270 °C at 10 °C/min. After holding at 270 °C for 40 min, the heat source was removed, and the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting Cu(0) NPs were precipitated with ethanol (20 mL), and separated by centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 5 min. The recovered NPs were washed in hexanes (1 mL) containing oleic acid (50 µL) and trioctylamine (50 µL), precipitated with ethanol (40 mL), and separated by centrifugation. Over the course of the nanoparticle recovery, the red Cu-NP suspension became dark green, indicative of oxidation in air to the final CuOx NPs. The recovered NPs were re-dispersed in hexanes (20 mL) containing oleic acid (50 µL) and trioctylamine (50 µL) and then centrifuged to remove larger Cu aggregates. The supernatant was recovered, dried under a stream of N2 and then stored in an N2-filled glovebox. 2.1.4 IE-Cu/BEA and NP-CuOx/BEA model catalysts The ion-exchanged Cu/BEA model catalyst, termed IE-Cu/BEA, was prepared according to our previous report, and had a measured Cu loading of 1.8 wt% after calcination at 500 °C.[27] The NP CuOx/BEA model catalysts was synthesized by adding a suspension of CuOx NPs in hexanes dropwise to a suspension of 3.86 g BEA (calcined in flowing dry air at 550 °C) in 80 mL of hexanes, targeting a Cu loading of 3.7 wt%. During dispersion, the mixture was sonicated for 5 min and recovered by centrifugation at 8000 rpm for 5 min. The resulting material was dried under vacuum overnight, and then calcined by heating to 400 °C at 2 °C/min and holding for 2 h in dry flowing air (500 sccm, Ultra Zero, Matheson) to remove residual organic species. The material was then reduced by heating to 300 °C at 2 °C/min and holding for 2 h in flowing 5 % H2/N2 (500 sccm, Matheson). After cooling to room temperature, the catalyst was passivated for 2 h in flowing 1 % O2/N2 (500 sccm, Matheson). The resulting material is denoted NP-CuOx/BEA. 2.1.5 Model post-reaction catalysts Model post-reaction catalysts were prepared by physically mixing NP-CuOx/BEA, IE-Cu/BEA, or fresh BEA with PR-BEA at a 1 to 1 mass ratio. Each mixture was ground together in a porcelain mortar and pestle to facilitate contact between the two materials. 2.2 Characterization 2.2.1 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) TEM imaging was performed using a FEI G2 ST30 Tecnai TEM operated at 300 kV. As-prepared CuOx NPs were drop-cast onto an ultrathin carbon-coated copper mesh grid (Ted Pella part no. 01824) from a hexanes suspension. The reduced and passivated NP-CuOx/BEA catalyst was dispersed in dry hexanes under air-free conditions and drop-cast onto a lacey carbon-coated copper mesh grid (Ted Pella part no. 01895-F). Air exposure was minimized prior to TEM imaging. Particle size distributions were collected using the ImageJ software package to manually measure at least 300 NPs per catalyst. 2.2.2 Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) XRD characterization was performed using a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer operated with a Cu Kα X-ray source set to 40 kV and 44 mA. As-prepared CuOx NPs were dropcast from a hexanes suspension onto a glass holder and powder NP-CuOx/BEA was pressed into a 0.5 mm deep recession on a glass holder. XRD patterns were measured over a 2θ range of 20 to 80° using a scan rate of 3°/min. Additional characterization of BEA and Cu/BEA catalysts can be found in previous reports.[17] Diffraction patterns were compared to ICDD standards for cubic Cu (powder diffraction file number 00-004-0836), monoclinic CuO (powder diffraction file number 01-077-7718), and cubic Cu2O (powder diffraction file number 01-071-3645). 2.2.3 Thermogravimetric analysis coupled with Fourier transform infrared (TGA-FTIR) spectroscopy TGA-FTIR spectroscopic analysis of catalysts mixtures was conducted using a SYS Evolution TGA instrument coupled with a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrophotometer. Fresh NP-CuOx/BEA, IE-Cu/BEA, and BEA catalysts that had been modified with nominally 10 wt% of solutions of pyrene (98 %, Sigma Aldrich) in toluene or 1-octadecene (90 %, Acros) in hexanes were also examined. In a typical analysis, 30 to 50 mg of catalyst sample was pretreated at 100 °C for 30 min in 50 sccm flowing N2 (UHP, Matheson) to remove adsorbed moisture. If oxidizing the sample, the carrier gas was switched to dry air (50 sccm, Ultra Zero, Matheson) at 100 °C and held for 10 min to stabilize the baseline signals for both TGA and IR spectroscopy. The sample was then heated to 800 °C at 20 °C/min in either flowing air or N2. IR spectra of the effluent gas were continuously collected every 30 s in the range of 400 – 4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The profiles for CO2, CO, water, and hydrocarbons were determined by integrating a characteristic peak for each species: 2240 – 2400 cm−1 for CO2, 2000–2240 cm−1 for CO, 1500–1800 cm−1 for water, and 2800 – 3100 cm−1 for hydrocarbons. Gaussian peaks and a constant baseline were used to fit the profiles using the Area under Peak package in the Igor Pro 9 software. 2.2.4 In situ diffuse reflectance ultraviolet–visible (DR-UV–Vis) spectroscopy In situ DR-UV–vis spectroscopy was conducted using an Agilent Cary 5000 UV–Vis–NIR spectrophotometer equipped with a Harrick Praying Mantis in situ diffuse reflectance cell. DR-UV–Vis spectra of the catalyst samples were collected over the range of 200 – 800 nm. The model catalyst mixtures were first measured at room temperature, then at varying temperatures up to 350 °C under 50 sccm dry air (Ultra Zero, Matheson) to study the evolution of surface hydrocarbon species. The catalysts were held at each temperature for 5 min to collect each spectrum. Additionally, series of in situ DR-UV–vis spectra were collected at 200 °C under 50 sccm dry air flow after 10, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 min from the start of sample heating. All in situ spectra were normalized to the intensity at the cutoff wavelength of the windows on the in situ cell (250 nm). The peak area between 287 nm and 500 nm in the DR-UV–vis spectra of the model catalysts were obtained using the Area under Peak package in the Igor Pro 9 software. 2.2.5 In situ Raman spectroscopy In situ Raman spectroscopy was conducted using a Horiba Jobin Yvon Raman system equipped with a Linkam Scientific Instrument CCR1000 Catalyst Cell Reactor. A 325 nm UV laser was used as the excitation source. Raman spectra were collected under 50 sccm flowing Ar (UHP, Matheson) after exposure to 50 sccm flowing air (Ultra Zero, Matheson) for 15 min at temperatures up to 400 °C to prevent laser-promoted oxidation during analysis. Additional series of in situ Raman spectra were collected at 300 °C under 50 sccm air flow after 10, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 min. Each spectrum was normalized to the intensity of the elastic scattering band (0 cm−1) in each spectrum. The region of interest (1000 – 2000 cm−1) in the Raman spectra was fitted with three Lorentzian peaks with a constant baseline to obtain the band area using the Multipeak Fitting package in the Igor Pro 9 software. 2.2.6 Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) The Cu loadings of the IE-Cu/BEA and NP-CuO x /BEA catalysts were determined by ICP-OES performed by Galbraith Laboratories Inc. (Knoxville, TN). 2.2.7 Acid site characterization by NH3 TPD Total acid site density was obtained from NH3 TPD experiments on an Altamira Instruments AMI-300Lite equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. All flow rates were held constant at 25 sccm. Approximately 100 mg of sample was loaded into a 6.4 mm O.D. quartz U-tube and held in place with a plug of quartz wool. The reactor was purged under flowing He (UHP, Matheson) for 1 h prior to pretreatment. Catalysts were pretreated in 10 % O2/He (Matheson) at 150 °C for 4 h using a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The sample was then cooled to 120 °C prior to 30 min of 10 % NH3/He (Matheson) dosing. The TPD was conducted after a 1 h He purge, which was done to remove physisorbed NH3. The temperature was increased under flowing He from 120 to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. Catalysts were held at 500 °C for 6 h to ensure complete NH3 desorption·NH3 signal calibration was done using 10 pulses of 10 % NH3/He from a 515 μL sample loop. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst synthesis and characterization Model catalysts containing only ionic Cu2+ or CuOx NPs supported on BEA zeolite were synthesized to explore the role of each Cu species in coke combustion. The targeted mass loading of individual Cu sites in the model catalysts were based on their loadings in a multifunctional Cu/BEA catalyst synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation, containing both site types as described previously by our group.[17] This multifunctional catalyst showed improved coke combustion activity relative to BEA and was found by X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) to contain 0.81 wt% ionic Cu2+ sites and 3.69 wt% metallic Cu after oxidation at 500 °C for 5 h followed by reduction in H2 at 300 °C for 2 h. Here, a model catalyst containing exclusively ionic Cu2+ species (IE-Cu/BEA) was synthesized using ion-exchange with a Cu(NO3)2 salt as previously described.[27] ICP-OES measurements determined that IE-Cu/BEA contained 1.8 wt% Cu. Previous X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) analysis indicated that IE-Cu/BEA contained only ionic Cu species, even after reduction in 3.5 % H2/He at 300 °C.[28] Similarly, extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements following a 300 °C reduction failed to identify Cu-Cu coordination typical of Cu metal.[28] As a result, it is assumed that IE-Cu/BEA has a Cu dispersion of 100 % (Table 1 ). Colloidal CuOx NPs were synthesized using a protocol modified from the literature.[31] XRD analysis of the as-prepared NPs indicated the presence of both Cu2O and metallic Cu, shown in Figure S1. TEM analysis of the NPs indicated an average diameter of 8.4 ± 1.6 nm shown in Fig. 1 A and B. After supporting the CuOx NPs on BEA, the material was oxidized at 400 °C to remove residual organic species, reduced at 300 °C to simulate pre-treatment of the multifunctional Cu/BEA catalyst described above, and then passivated in 1 % O2. XRD analysis of the supported material indicated the potential presence of CuO, Cu2O, and metallic Cu phases (Figure S1) but cannot definitively identify Cu species above the baseline BEA pattern. The CuOx NPs maintained their size distribution after immobilization onto BEA, with an average diameter of 7.5 ± 1.8 nm as shown in Fig. 1C and D. The dispersion of the NPs was estimated to be 14 % using the lattice constant of Cu, the average NP diameter from TEM measurement of NP-CuOx/BEA, and the assumption that the supported NPs are hemispherical (supporting information).[32] A Cu loading of 3.4 wt% was determined for the NP-CuOx/BEA catalyst using ICP-OES. Both the loading and size distribution of the NP-CuOx/BEA align well with the NP Cu fraction of the Cu/BEA catalyst prepared by incipient wetness impregnation, which contained Cu NPs with an average diameter of 7.8 ± 2.5 nm after conducting DME homologation for 24 h followed by regeneration at 450 °C in air for 8 h (PR IWI-Cu/BEA Fig. 1E and F). The loadings and dispersions of the model catalysts are reported in Table 1 along with the calculated concentrations of Cu and acid sites. Based on the concentration of sites determined in Table 1, NP-CuOx/BEA, is calculated to contain approximately 25 % the Cu site density of IE-Cu/BEA. All catalysts had similar acid site densities as determined by NH3 temperature programmed desorption (TPD), ranging from 1757 to 1812 µmolNH3/g. IE-Cu/BEA, NP-CuOx/BEA, and fresh BEA catalysts were physically mixed in a 1:1 mass ratio with a post reaction BEA catalyst (PR-BEA) used for the homologation of DME to hydrocarbons for 24 h. Past work has demonstrated that different Cu species lead to the formation of coke with different characteristics such as graphitic coke content and combustion temperatures.[19,29] Utilizing PR-BEA as the coked component combined with each model catalyst enabled comparison of the role of different Cu species on the removal of a uniform coke material. Scheme 1 provides a guide for the relationship between the mixtures of catalysts and PR-BEA studied in this report. The coke present on PR-BEA has been previously shown to contain both molecular hydrocarbon species, such as alkenes and aromatics, as well as graphitic and disordered polyaromatics.[10] Our initial investigation using mixed fresh and PR materials proved to be suitable to probe the role of Cu sites on the fresh catalyst in the removal/combustion of coke from the PR catalyst as demonstrated by similar coke combustion TGA profiles for PR-Cu/BEA and a physical mixture of PR-BEA with fresh Cu/BEA.[10]. All catalyst mixtures were first analyzed using DR-UV–Vis and Raman spectroscopies to confirm that coke species observed on PR-BEA could be observed in the catalyst mixtures. DR-UV–Vis spectroscopy can be used to determine the speciation of hydrocarbon molecules and has been extensively employed for characterization of post-reaction catalysts from a variety of reactions.[33,34] Fig. 2 A shows the DR-UV–Vis spectra for PR-BEA and for Cu-containing catalyst mixtures. All spectra contain similar features at 300, 380, 420, and 456 nm. These peaks have been assigned to a variety of unsaturated carbocations common within catalyst coke,[33–35] and previously observed in coked PR-BEA.[10] Specifically, the peak at 300 nm has been assigned to monoenyl carbocations,[33,34] the peak at 380 nm to alkyl benzene and dienyl carbocations,[33,35] the peak at 420 nm to alkylated naphthene carbocations,[33,34] and the peak at 456 nm to polyaromatic and trienyl carbocations.[33,34] Table S1 contains a detailed list of assignments for the peaks observed. As expected, all spectra appeared similar, indicating that IE-Cu/BEA and NP-CuOx/BEA did not include additional detectable carbonaceous species. Similarly, Raman spectroscopy was implemented to characterize polycyclic carbon species, such as graphitic carbon as shown in Fig. 2B.[36,37] Three distinct peaks at 1200, 1375, and 1600 cm−1 labeled S, D, and G respectively were observed for all catalyst mixtures. Detailed Raman peak assignments are presented in Table S2. The G peak is typically assigned to ring stretching in graphite, while the D peak is ascribed to ring stretching in disordered graphite, and the S peak to C–C stretching in polyaromatics.[36,37] Raman spectroscopy analysis indicated that all catalyst mixtures displayed similar coke species to those found on PR-BEA, in agreement with the DR-UV–Vis spectroscopy analysis. 3.2 Coke combustion To evaluate coke removal, the mixtures were oxidized during thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) coupled with Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy to analyze the gas-phase products evolved as a function of temperature. The CO2, CO, H2O, and hydrocarbons (HCs) FTIR signals were monitored and are presented in Fig. 3 as they can be used to indicate the onset of coke combustion (CO2, CO, and H2O) and desorption (HCs). Fig. 3 presents integrated FTIR peak areas as well as mass loss from TGA as a function of temperature. The mass loss for PR-BEA was 11.7 wt% between 100 and 800 °C, while the mass loss for the model catalyst mixtures were 4.8, 4.8, and 5.3 wt% for BEA + PR-BEA, NP-Cu/BEA + PR-BEA, and IE-Cu/BEA + PR-BEA respectively. The lower mass losses of the mixtures agree with mixtures containing half the starting coke of PR-BEA and indicate that the fresh catalysts did not introduce other combustible species to the mixtures. The catalyst mixtures without Cu reached a maximum CO2 production rate near 500 °C. This result agrees with literature reports indicating that Brønsted acid sites are able to perform combustion starting at 300 °C through the formation of carbocation species, with coke combustion activity increasing at higher temperatures.[12,13] Conversely, catalyst mixtures containing Cu exhibited CO2 production maxima at lower temperatures, with NP-CuOx/BEA + PR-BEA exhibiting a maximum at 300 °C and IE-Cu/BEA + PR-BEA at 325 °C. The lower temperature of maximum CO2 evolution for Cu-containing catalysts relative to catalysts without Cu is comparable to the low temperature oxidation activity observed for CuOx supported on ZSM-5,[20,21] and to our previous work studying PR-Cu/BEA.[10] Similar results have also been observed for other metals added to zeolites including Pd,[9] Pt,[38] Fe,[39] and Gd.[38] Both IE-Cu/BEA + PR-BEA and NP-CuOx/BEA + PR-BEA exhibited a second CO2 evolution peak near 500 °C, similar to the catalysts that did not contain Cu. This second peak, observed in all catalyst mixtures, indicates that Brønsted acid sites still play a role in coke combustion. Specifically, acid sites likely play a role in the combustion of coke species that are either difficult to combust at low temperatures or that require high temperatures to become mobile. The CO2 evolution peaks from IE-Cu/BEA + PR-BEA and NP-CuOx/BEA + PR-BEA were fit with two Gaussian peaks, as shown in Figure S2 to estimate the fraction of coke that was combusted at low temperatures by the Cu species. This analysis revealed that NP-CuOx/BEA + PR-BEA evolved a greater fraction of carbon dioxide in the low temperature region, 69 %, relative to IE-Cu/BEA + PR-BEA, which produced 57 % of its CO2 at the lower temperature. This difference, along with the lower temperature of maximum CO2 production over CuOx NPs is in agreement with literature reports describing metal-containing nanoparticles to be more effective combustion catalysts than dispersed single atoms due to their increased ability to activate molecular oxygen between adjacent surface metal atoms.[21,40,41]. Beyond CO2, several other species were desorbed from the catalysts during the temperature programmed oxidation. All catalyst mixtures evolved water between 100 and 400 °C as a product of low temperature combustion. Water could also be produced by dehydrogenation of hydrocarbon coke species with subsequent H2 oxidation.[13,42] In the case of PR-BEA alone, a small quantity of hydrocarbons were also observed below 200 °C due to desorption without combustion, as reported previously.[10] Finally, the IE-Cu/BEA + PR-BEA mixture produced a small amount of CO near its peak production of CO2. This partial oxidation selectivity could be a result of inefficient O2 activation by ionic Cu species preventing complete combustion or the known activity of dispersed Cu atoms inside zeolites for selective oxidation.[22,23] Overall, these TGA-FTIR spectroscopic data indicate the beneficial role played by Cu species to lower the temperature for coke combustion. To better understand the role of Cu on the oxidation of different coke species, in situ DR-UV–Vis and Raman spectroscopy experiments were conducted with catalyst mixtures to observe changes in molecular hydrocarbon and graphitic species on the catalysts, respectively, during temperature programmed oxidation. In both analyses, catalyst mixtures were heated from room temperature in flowing air, collecting spectra every 50 °C. In situ DR-UV–Vis spectra in Fig. 4 A-C indicate that all catalyst combinations lost hydrocarbon species as the temperature increased. This loss was particularly pronounced for the Cu-containing catalysts at temperatures below 200 °C, as highlighted in Fig. 4D, which tracks the difference in total peak area at each temperature relative to the peak area measured at 25 °C before thermal oxidation. This low temperature hydrocarbon loss contrasts with the TGA-FTIR spectroscopy results in Fig. 3, that indicated no significant CO2 evolution below 200 °C. However, it is possible that the addition of Cu-containing materials to PR-BEA aided in hydrocarbon condensation reactions, where volatile hydrocarbons (e.g., the desorbed hydrocarbons observed in TGA-FTIR spectroscopy from PR-BEA alone) dehydrogenate and aromatize to form graphitic species, forming water as an observable by-product from H2 oxidation.[42] This hypothesis is supported by (1) these DR-UV–Vis spectroscopic data for BEA + PR-BEA showing hydrocarbon loss in a similar temperature regime as in the TGA-FTIR spectra, and (2) the increased evolution of water at low temperatures by Cu containing catalysts in the TGA-FTIR spectroscopic analysis. All catalysts exhibited near complete removal of hydrocarbon species in the DR-UV–Vis spectra by 350 °C. Similarly, all catalyst mixtures exhibited a loss of graphitic species when heated in air, as monitored by in situ Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 5 A-C). Fig. 5D calculates the area of the G band Raman spectrum peak at a given temperature relative to the G band area at 25 °C before thermal oxidation. This allows for tracking the removal of graphitic species from the catalyst mixtures. An uncertainty of 5 % on the normalized scale can be expected based on replicate measurements at room temperature. Fig. 5D indicates that all catalysts lost their graphitic coke at a similar rate up to approximately 300 °C. At this temperature, the relative peak area for BEA + PR-BEA began to stabilize while the peak areas for NP-CuOx/BEA + PR-BEA and IE-Cu/BEA + PR-BEA continued to decrease, indicating further removal of graphitic coke above 300 °C. This analysis highlights that the addition of Cu enhanced the removal of graphitic species above 300 °C. This finding, along with the enhanced rate of graphitic coke removal from NP-CuOx/BEA + PR-BEA relative to IE-Cu/BEA + PR-BEA above 300 °C agrees with the increased CO2 evolution from these catalysts highlighted in the TGA-FTIR spectra in Fig. 3. Improved graphitic combustion activity for NP-CuOx/BEA relative to IE-Cu/BEA is also in agreement with the literature on aromatics combustion over PdOx, which suggest that multiple binding sites between the adsorbate and the metal-containing catalyst surface are needed for increased activity.[43] As a result, ionic Cu+2 sites would be expected to be less active for the combustion of graphitic species due to their lack of multiple binding sites in close proximity to one another. To further investigate differences in the performance of each catalyst combination in the removal of hydrocarbon and graphitic coke, in situ DR-UV–Vis and Raman spectroscopy experiments were conducted in flowing air at fixed temperatures relevant to the removal of the coke species being probed. DR-UV–Vis spectroscopy experiments were performed at a fixed temperature of 200 °C in flowing air, which yielded different hydrocarbon removal levels for the three catalyst mixtures during the temperature programmed in situ DR-UV–Vis spectroscopy experiments (Fig. 4D). The resulting in situ DR-UV–Vis spectra for the catalyst mixtures collected at 200 °C are presented in Fig. 6 A-C, and the integrated fractions of total hydrocarbon peak area relative to those of the catalyst mixtures at 25 °C are plotted in Fig. 6D. In all cases, the largest decrease in hydrocarbon signal was observed within the first 10 min of thermal oxidation as the catalysts were heated to 200 °C. In line with results of the temperature-programmed in situ DR-UV–Vis spectroscopy experiments (Fig. 4D), the Cu-containing catalyst mixtures exhibited greater removal of hydrocarbons than BEA + PR-BEA (80–85 % reduction in peak areas versus 50–60 %), and exhibited a more rapid rate of removal, reaching the baseline hydrocarbon concentration more quickly (8 % reduction of peak area after reaching 200 °C) than BEA + PR-BEA (19 % reduction of peak area after reaching 200 °C). In situ Raman spectroscopy measurements were conducted at a constant temperature of 300 °C in air, informed by the temperature-programmed analysis shown in Fig. 5D where NP-CuOx/BEA exhibited a greater coke removal rate than the other catalysts above 300 °C. Raman spectra are displayed in Fig. 7 A-C and the remaining fraction of graphitic coke signal in the G band is displayed in Fig. 7D. Again, a large fraction of the peak area (40–70 %) was lost as the catalyst mixtures were heated to 300 °C, consistent with the data in Fig. 5. However, once 300 °C was reached, the BEA + PR-BEA mixture did not lose additional peak area, indicating that at 300 °C, this catalyst mixture was unable to further oxidize the graphitic coke species observable by Raman spectroscopy. The NP-CuOx/BEA + PR-BEA lost 70 % of the graphitic coke peak area by 300 °C and maintained a low rate of coke removal at this temperature. Following heating at 300 °C for 120 min, the peak areas representative of graphitic carbon for NP-CuOx/BEA + PR-BEA were 20 % of the initial value compared to 40 % on BEA + PR-BEA. This time-resolved analysis indicates that the addition of NP-CuOx enabled greater removal of graphitic coke, in agreement with the temperature-programmed data presented in Fig. 5D. This result also agrees with literature reports that suggest that CuOx can become active for hydrocarbon combustion around 250 °C.[21] Finally, IE-Cu/BEA + PR-BEA exhibited a slower rate of graphitic coke removal, requiring 60 min at 300 °C to reach a stable signal of about 40 % the initial area. This final value is similar to that of BEA + PR-BEA, suggesting that IE-Cu/BEA graphitic coke removal activity is primarily driven by zeolite acid sites rather than the Cu ions. All catalysts were unable to completely remove graphitic species at 300 °C, requiring thermal oxidation at temperatures above 600 °C for complete removal (Fig. 3). We propose that this could be due to either the inability of large coke species to diffuse from PR-BEA to fresh catalyst grains at 300 °C or low catalytic activity at 300 °C. In support of the first hypothesis, BEA + PR-BEA and IE-Cu/BEA + PR-BEA are likely to be limited in graphitic coke removal by the fact that the majority of their active sites reside within the micropores of the BEA structure, which could exclude large coke species formed on the exterior of PR-BEA. On the other hand, NP-CuOx/BEA + PR-BEA contains metal active sites on the exterior of the catalyst particles which are accessible to mobile graphitic coke species. We note that it is also possible that the catalyst mixtures are insufficiently active at 300 °C or that not all coke species on PR-BEA are mobile at the lower temperature and can only be removed at 600 °C. 3.3 Model compound removal Finally, to explore the combustion of hydrocarbon and graphitic coke species on the catalysts without coke diffusional barriers, model coke compounds were deposited directly onto the surface of BEA, IE-Cu/BEA, and NP-CuOx/BEA and their removal was observed using TGA. Pyrene was selected to represent graphitic coke species based on its polycyclic nature and 1-octadecene was chosen as a model compound for aliphatic hydrocarbons similar to those observed by DR-UV–Vis spectroscopy. Both model compounds were selected due to their high boiling points that enables observation of combustion rather than volatilization in TGA. Pyrene and 1-octadecene were added to each catalyst at a nominal loading of 10 wt%, similar to the coke content of PR-BEA determined by TGA analysis in Fig. 1A. TGA data were collected in both oxidizing and inertatmospheres to allow for deconvolution of thermal desorption and oxidation effects. Fig. 8 A-F compare the mass loss from each material under oxidizing and inertatmospheres for each model compound. At temperatures below 300 °C, all catalyst-model compound systems showed similar mass loss behavior for both oxidizing and inert conditions in Fig. 8A, C, and E. This similarity between conditions suggests that the mass loss at these temperatures is driven by thermal cracking and desorption of the model compounds. However, starting at 300 °C, all catalysts exhibited a plateau in mass loss under oxidizing conditions, while inert conditions continued to lose mass. This divergence could be accounted for by partial oxidation of the deposited carbon species, a known initial step in coke removal.[5] Beyond resulting in a slight mass gain, the oxygenated species bind more strongly to the surface of the catalyst than hydrocarbons, hindering their thermal desorption.[44] The mass loss plateau under oxidizing conditions ended near 400 °C, where all catalysts exhibited an increased rate of mass loss under oxidizing conditions. This change is an indicator of the start of combustion reactions. To visualize the difference between the inert and oxidizing atmospheres for model compound removal, Fig. 8G and 8H plot the difference in sample mass loss between oxidizing and inert conditions as a function of temperature. Positive values in these plots indicate that the catalyst lost more mass under inert conditions while negative values indicate a greater mass loss under oxidizing conditions. All catalysts showed a positive difference between 200 °C and 300 °C, attributed to the partial oxidation of the coke model compounds under oxidizing conditions. Cu-containing catalysts achieved a transition to negative values at lower temperatures (between 400 °C and 500 °C) than BEA (580 °C). This trend agrees with TGA-FTIR, DR-UV–Vis, and Raman spectroscopy results discussed above suggesting that Cu-containing materials achieved oxidation at lower temperatures. NP-CuOx/BEA exhibited even lower temperature transitions (434 °C and 388 °C) than IE-Cu/BEA (488 °C and 511 °C) for 1-octadecene and pyrene, respectively, suggesting it is best suited to combusting both model compounds. It is notable that the transition temperature difference between NP-CuOx/BEA and IE-Cu/BEA is smaller for 1-octadecene (54 °C) than for pyrene (123 °C), indicating a greater difference in the combustion of graphitic model compounds relative to aliphatic hydrocarbons. This result agrees with NP-CuOx/BEA showing greater graphitic carbon removal in Raman spectroscopy than IE-Cu/BEA while both materials performed similarly in DR-UV–Vis spectroscopy experiments that tracked molecular hydrocarbon removal. Fig. 8G and 8H also provide the final difference in model compound removed between the inert and oxidizing conditions. NP-CuOx/BEA exhibited the greatest mass loss differences (4 % and 9.5 %) for 1-octadecene and pyrene, respectively, while BEA exhibited the smallest mass loss differences (1 % and 4.5 %) for both model compounds. IE-Cu/BEA displayed intermediate mass losses (2 % and 6.5 %) for 1-octadecene and pyrene, respectively. The smaller final mass loss differences for 1-octadecene relative to pyrene can be attributed to its higher volatility, meaning more would evaporate under inert conditions. These mass loss difference trends support Raman spectroscopy results that suggested that NP-CuOx/BEA outperformed BEA in graphitic carbon combustion with IE-Cu/BEA showing intermediate activity, but only above 350 °C. The mass loss differences for 1-octadecene disagree with the DR-UV–Vis results in Fig. 4D where all materials performed similarly for hydrocarbon removal up to 350 °C. However, 1-octadecene combustion occurred above 350 °C, the maximum temperature examined in the DR-UV–Vis spectroscopy experiment. 3.4 Discussion From the multi-faceted analysis described above, a picture of coke removal over the active sites in the multifunctional Cu/BEA can be proposed. As we previously reported, the addition of Cu to BEA decreased the temperature of overall coke combustion.[10] However, the data presented here provide a better understanding of the role of CuOx NPs and ionic Cu2+ species in removal of specific coke species, which is represented in Scheme 2 . From TGA-FTIR, DR-UV–Vis, and Raman spectroscopy data, it can be concluded that CuOx NPs outperform ionic Cu2+ species for the removal of coke on a site normalized basis, especially graphitic species. This conclusion is supported by NP-CuOx/BEA + PR-BEA producing a greater fraction of CO2 at low temperatures in TGA-FTIR spectroscopy, removing graphitic coke at a higher rate at lower temperatures in Raman spectroscopy, and combusting graphitic model compounds at lower temperatures as assessed by TGA, all while possessing a Cu site density 75 % lower than IE-Cu/BEA. Interestingly, the activity of NP-CuOx/BEA + PR-BEA and IE-Cu/BEA + PR-BEA are more similar when observing combustion of molecular hydrocarbon species than graphitic species. For instance, both Cu species removed these hydrocarbon species similarly in DR-UV–Vis spectroscopic analysis, which primarily tracks alkenes and mono-aromatic species, and in the TGA combustion of 1-octadecene. This difference in performance with different coke species could be a result of limited access for large graphitic species to IE-Cu/BEA active sites within BEA micropores or different intrinsic activities of the sites for combusting the two coke species classes. 4 Conclusions The role of ion-exchanged Cu2+ and NP-CuOx species on BEA zeolite for the removal of coke deposited during DME homologation under mild conditions (200 °C and 1 atm) was investigated through a variety of in situ spectroscopic techniques including TGA-FTIR, DR-UV–Vis, and Raman spectroscopy as well as by the combustion of model coke species. Importantly, all coke combustion studies were performed using an identical coked catalyst in combination with model catalysts BEA, IE-Cu/BEA, and NP-CuOx/BEA, ensuring that all catalysts were tested with a uniform coke material. These experiments suggest that while the addition of Cu in all forms results in improved coke removal relative to BEA alone, NP-CuOx is better able to combust coke, especially graphitic species. Two possible explanations for the difference in graphitic coke combustion behavior between ionic Cu2+ and CuOx are (1) the introduction of diffusional barriers by locating ionic species throughout the BEA host surface area, which is primarily micropores, and (2) a lower intrinsic activity for aromatics combustion over the ionic species. The diffusional barrier hypothesis is supported by IE-Cu/BEA behaving similarly to unmodified BEA up to 350 to 400 °C in both in situ Raman spectroscopy of coked catalyst mixtures and TGA experiments with pyrene as a model compound. Since both catalysts contain most of their active sites within narrow micropores, it is possible they both faced the same diffusional barriers up to these temperatures. However, this difference could also be explained by the ionic Cu species having minimal intrinsic activity for the combustion of graphitic species below 350 °C. At these low temperatures, it is not expected that Brønsted acid sites would be active for the combustion of graphitic species and both catalysts could be losing coke species due to volatilization at the same rate.[11,12] It has been shown that ionic Cu species have minimal activity for O2 activation, a key step for combustion, below 350 °C while CuOx NPs are known to be catalytically active for propane combustion at temperatures as low as 250 °C.[21,45] The results of this study agree with literature on oxidation of hydrocarbon species,[20,40,41] and coke combustion in particular.[9] The detailed understanding of the impact of Cu speciation on removal of different types of carbon species developed here can be used to inform effective catalyst regeneration protocols that remove coke while avoiding severe temperatures that could accelerate catalyst degradation. coredata.dc:description: Active site occlusion by carbon species, often referred to as coke, is a common deactivation mechanism for heterogeneous catalysts. While it is known that transition metals can lower the temperature required for oxidative coke removal, the roles of ionic species and metal nanoparticles in coke removal are not well understood. This work aims to differentiate how ionic and nanoparticle Cu sites catalyze oxidative regeneration of a coked beta (BEA) zeolite catalyst. This was accomplished by synthesizing catalysts containing exclusively CuOx nanoparticles (NPs) or Cu2+ ions supported on BEA, physically mixing Cu/BEA with a coked BEA catalyst, and monitoring coke removal using in situ spectroscopy. Our results point to an improved combustion activity for CuOx NPs relative to Cu2+ ions, especially in the combustion of graphitic-type coke species. This improved understanding of coke combustion in transition metal containing catalysts informs strategies to improve catalyst regeneration, thereby increasing operational lifetimes.
